Belgia 1591 xi July To my L Trea
s

page.lettertext:
May it please yo
r
good L. to be adv
r
tised,
t
the 5 of
this moneth when
e
Count
w
th
all his troupes was come before
Steenwick,
there came intelligence from all quarters, that
the ennemy was entred the Betuwe fast by
Neumegen.
There came also many letters from
e
g
na
l States
, the
Provinces of
Gueldres
&
Utrecht,
the
Count of Cullemborg
,
e
Ammand of Tiel
, & others requiring very earnestly, that
e
enterprise of Steenwick & all oth
r
purposes sett apart,
e
camp should come forward to
e assistance of those places
w
ch
e ennemy might oth
r
wise very mightely eldommage
upon this intelligence &
e instance of
e Countrey, it was
p
nt
ly resolved that they would not staie at Steenwick, & so
much
e rath
r
for
t
e Count &
e armie were nothing yet
engaged, neither by summoning the towne, nor planting theyr
artillery, nor by quartering
e comp
ies
, nor by any other action
that might make theyr de
ture p
r
judiciall to theyr honor.
Howbeit for
e better p
r
servation of those places, that were
taken about
Groninghen,
yt was deemed expedient that
Count
William
w
th
his troupes of
Friseland
w
ch
were to
e nomber
of 2000 should remaine stil in Frise, & that Count Maurice
w
th
e rest, making at
e least by all conjecture, 5000 foote
& 1300 horse should m
r
che toward
Arnham,
upon w
ch
resolution all o
r
forces, aswell of horsmen as footmen
arrived yesterday heer, wher wee hope to be renforced, from
out of
e garisons of those quarters w
th
2000 men more.
The furnishing of those fort
that were taken about
Groningen amonting by tale to 32 in all, did greatly
diminish
e strength of o
r
army, Nevertheles for ought
t
wee can learne by prisoners, spies & other meanes the
ennemy for footmen is weaker then wee are, but his horsmen
yt is thought are 2000 at
e least, moreover wee do finde
that
e
Duke
him self in
son, w
th
all his forces, 2 regim
t
of footmen & 4 cornet
of horse excepted w
ch
are left
behinde
beside Nieumegen for
e custodye of theyr baggage, are
alredy in
e Betuwe. He hath also made his approche
& planted 8 peeces of battery before
Cnossenburg,
w
ch
is that
fort w
ch
wee built
e last sommer on this side
e Wael
fol.177v
before
e towne of Nieumegen. Albeyt wee have sent abroad
very many to learne his dessignes &
e state of his army
yet we finde theyr informations to differ so much, that
wee can build upon nothing, but that they are in some misery
for want of vittailes, wherin all do accord./ They are
s
ved of
theyr vittailes from
Collen,
Bosleduck,
Grave
, & from
e Land
of
Cleve,
by
e way of
Emmerick,
from whence they bring
it all by land to certaine places by Nieumegen, & there
transport yt by scutes to
e Ennemyes Camp./ They have passed
all theyr troupes both horse & foote, w
th
2 great pontons
of w
ch
either ys thought sufficient for 300 men at a passage./
This strange aventure of
e Duke, in comming over
e river
doth wonderfully astonish
e people of this countrey, who are
all of one opinion, that hee hath put himself in so much
danger, as hee cannot any waie go back, w
th
out notable
losse. To
e effecting wh
r
of heer are 2 waies proposed
the one by sending over o
r
forces to Nieumegen side, therby
to cut of his vittailes, & to stopp his returne, the other
by passing
e Rhene heer at Arnham, & by marching in
e
Betuwe directly toward
him, w
th
such good cautions for
the order of theyr marche, for
e making of trenches, & for
usinge other martiall meanes, as they will either have in
choise to fighte if they list, or being forced th
r
unto, to doe yt
w
th
out
e hazard of the body of theyr army./ But howsoev
r
wee hope it is a waie to relieve that fort in some sort, that
is p
nt
ly besieged, & before
e ennemy shuld recover
e other side
of
e river to cut of some
te of
e arriergarde of his
army./ Howbeyt
e forte, though w
th
in yt bee all thinge
requesit, & 800 men in garrison, yet wee dout yt wilbe
taken or surrendred in
e end./ as wee also make acchount when
the Duke ys gon to recover yt ag ain. Of
e foresayd 2
waies because
e first is subject to very many difficulties, &
would be too long in
fourming, considering
t
e troupes
are
to passe over 3 rivers, they are wholy as yet inclined
to put
the latter in execution, for w
ch
theyr bridge for the
Rhine is
alredy
vided, & wilbe happely placed some time
to day
fol.178r
so as all
e souldiers may passe out toward
night.
And this is in summe the state of o
r
affaires, w
ch
I do
signify c
o
tinually, as messengers & matter are p
nt
ed wher I
am,
And so I take &c. From Arnham, July 11 1591.
postscript.
Wee do not yet understand that
e ennemy hath begon his
battery, but those w
th
in
e fort do shute continually
& have either slaine or very dangerously hurtt the
Count Octavio
broth
r
to
Count Mansfelt
, & divers other
captaines.
